answer_1.text: George Washington was born in 1732 to a prominent Virginia planter family, which instilled values of hard work, discipline, and respect for social hierarchy. His upbringing on a tobacco plantation exposed him to the challenges of managing land and labor, shaping his leadership style to emphasize organization and responsibility. The social norms of colonial Virginia, including an emphasis on honor and duty, influenced his moral compass and commitment to public service, solidifying his role as a leader during the American Revolution and as the first President.
